<section class="osci-tk-epub-section tombstone" id="tombstone">Girl in Plumed Hat (Mlle Antoinette)  
Nice, 1919  
Pen and black inks on cream wove paper; 27 × 36.6 cm (10 5/8 × 14 3/8 in.)  
Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower right, in graphite)  
The Art Institute of Chicago, gift of the Arts Club of Chicago, 1927.1616

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section curatorial_entry" id="curatorial_entry">In November 1918, Henri Matisse moved into the Hôtel de la Méditerranée in Nice. It was while living there that he created what scholars often refer to as the “plumed hat” series (see fig. 29.1, fig. 29.2, fig. 29.3, fig. 29.4, fig. 29.5, fig. 29.6, and fig. 29.7), which includes the Art Institute’s Girl in Plumed Hat (Mlle Antoinette). As with many of his paintings and drawings from this time, Matisse used the nineteen-year-old Antoinette Arnoux as his model.

In this work, Arnoux wears an elaborate hat with a large ostrich feather that sweeps its way across the brim. Matisse lavished attention on the individual strands of her hair as well as on the fine details of the plume. He may have drawn inspiration from the Promenade des Anglais. Just outside his hotel, it was a choice spot to observe the latest fashions as vacationing Europeans strolled along the sea, and the hat depicted in Matisse’s series, with its large, wispy ostrich feather, was a prime example of a fashion-forward chapeau.

Nice was dotted with shops offering millinery supplies from ribbons to large feathers in order for visitors to replicate the trends modeled on the promenade. In fact, Matisse constructed the ornate, plumed hat he depicted himself. Margaret Scolari Barr, an art historian and the wife of the Museum of Modern Art’s founding director, Alfred H. Barr, asked Matisse about it while standing in front of his painting White Plumes (1919; fig. 29.1)—the culmination of the plumed hat drawings—at his 1931 retrospective in Paris. She recollected:

I asked him where in creation he’d got that hat, so he laughed welcoming the question and said he’d made it himself. He bought the straw foundation and the feathers and the black ribbon and put it together with pins on the model’s head. He said he had too much black ribbon so that he had to stuff it into the crown with dozens of pins.

These details can also be seen in the Art Institute’s drawing, even the woven straw base is represented by the intricate latticework of lines visible just beyond the ostrich feather at the top of the sheet. Around the time Matisse made the drawing, he told a visitor to his studio that the large plume was “an ornament, a decorative element, but it is also a material; one can feel, so to speak, its lightness, and the down seems so soft, impalpable, one could very well be tempted to blow it away.” In Girl in Plumed Hat (Mlle Antoinette), the loose, wispy lines that define the feather are layered at the edges with a shiny, black ink, reinforcing its fluffy texture. Cascading down the sides of the hat, the ribbons are almost tactile—the velvety ink dried on the surface of the paper forms an opaque layer of media that creates a depth and richness suggestive of the many layers of ribbon pinned to the base of the hat.

Matisse explored a wide range of moods in his plumed hat series, depicting Arnoux in various roles as if she were an actress in a play. In one drawing (fig. 29.3) she appears rather innocent and demure, her head tilted ever so slightly, and is drowning in a large robe and oversized hat as if she were playing dress-up in her mother’s closet. In another rendering (fig. 29.4) she is regal and poised. Her left hand, adorned with a wedding band—a prop, Arnoux was unmarried—firmly clutches the arm of a chair as she confidently gazes off into the distance. Alfred Barr situated the Art Institute’s drawing within the series as “the strangest of all . . . the monstrous hat, bristling and tentacular, as it settles down over the model’s face and shoulders.” The hat appears to take on a life of its own as the rhythm of the curve of the ribbons and the model’s hair over her left shoulder blurs the boundaries between accessory and model. Arnoux’s presence, however, is not entirely lost within the composition. The curve of her chin and her soft lips pierce through the finery of the hat and provide a glimpse of the young model underneath.  
Mel Becker Solomon

</section><section class="osci-tk-epub-section technical_report" id="technical_report">Henri Matisse chose pen and two black inks to explore the linear structure of the feather, fabric, and hair in this drawing on cream wove paper. Strong, raking light readily reveals the difference in sheen between the two black inks and how he drew the majority of the composition in matte black ink using both fluid and dry pen strokes. The dry pen strokes produced broken, gray lines as the pen deposited ink only on the top of the faintly textured surface, as in the sitter’s hair. The fluid strokes generated solid lines as seen in the profile contour (see fig. 29.8). In this way, the artist laid in the textured masses of the ostrich feather sweeping down from the hat brim, curling ribbons, flowing hair, and fabric embracing the sitter’s shoulders. Matisse reserved the shiny, deep-black ink for articulating major outlines, including the profile of the face and the shoulders, and applied it fluidly. These firm outlines give just the suggestion of solidity beneath the airy masses of feathers and hair. He also applied this resinous ink over the matte ink throughout to add depth and thereby develop the three-dimensional character of forms and differentiate among materials of similar textures. He created the deep-black curls of ribbon hanging off the back of the hat by layering the shiny black ink over the matte ink until the strokes merged into thick, glossy bands. There are pinholes at all corners, which may indicate Matisse drew with the paper pinned to a board.

Signed: Henri-Matisse (lower right, in graphite) (fig. 29.9).

Matisse used pen and two different black inks that can be differentiated visually with raking light and with microscope examination. One is more matte and gray-black; the other is a deeper, shiny black with a higher resin content.

The support is medium thick, smooth, cream wove paper. The sheet is straight cut at the top and sides. The lower edge is slightly uneven, as if torn from a sketchbook. The sheet dimensions remain unchanged since Matisse drew this work; ink extends onto the sheet edges.

27 × 36.6 cm (10 5/8 × 14 7/16 in.).

At some point a backing was removed from the verso (fig. 29.10) of this drawing, leaving brown adhesive staining and fiber residue across it. It is not known when or where this occurred. The drawing underwent conservation treatment in 2014–15 to reduce the mount residue. In addition, surface soil was reduced, minor edge tears were repaired, and skinning in one spot on the verso located in the lower left was reinforced with Japanese paper and wheat starch paste. Multiple campaigns of paper hinges were removed from the verso and planar distortions induced by those hinges were eliminated.

The sheet has discolored to a darker, yellower tone. The right and left edges are lighter and likely retain the original color. There is a golden-brown stain, possibly a fingerprint, near the lower right corner. There are minor edge tears that have been repaired. On the verso, there is a pattern of golden-brown staining imparted by a former mount. The sheet has a subtle backward curl at the top and lower edges.  
Kristi Dahm
